articles.headline: After Deadly Floods, a German Village Rethinks Its Relationship to Nature
articles.snippet: A long history of bad land use decisions exacerbated the death toll and damage of Germany’s recent megaflood. Some say now is the time to rebuild differently.
articles.abstract: A long history of bad land use decisions exacerbated the death toll and damage of Germany’s recent megaflood. Some say now is the time to rebuild differently.
articles.lead_paragraph: RECH, Germany — Shortly before midnight Dominik Gieler received one last WhatsApp message from his mother. She had watched as a tsunami of river first took one, then two, then all of the houses around her own. “I won’t make it out of here,” she told him.

articles.headline: Tokyo Was Promised Glory and Riches. It Got an Olympics in a Bubble.
articles.snippet: The Games failed to live up to their economic promise and cast a harsh light on Japan’s political culture. Some feel “a hunger for a new system.”
articles.abstract: The Games failed to live up to their economic promise and cast a harsh light on Japan’s political culture. Some feel “a hunger for a new system.”
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Tokyo’s leaders promised glory and riches when the Japanese capital won its bid to host the 2020 Summer Olympics. Jobs and the economy would grow. The public would rally in support. Japan’s international stature would rise.
articles.byline: By Ben Dooley, Hikari Hida and Hisako Ueno

articles.headline: Why Do We Make Things So Hard for Renters?
articles.snippet: Relief came late, then slowly, and renters have been subject to political brinkmanship. We can do better.
articles.abstract: Relief came late, then slowly, and renters have been subject to political brinkmanship. We can do better.
articles.lead_paragraph: For struggling homeowners in the pandemic’s first year, there was hope early on that these hard times would not put people with mortgages out in the street.

articles.headline: They Don’t Want the Shot. They Don’t Want Colleagues to Know.
articles.snippet: Nearly 40 percent of Americans over the age of 18 remain unvaccinated, and could return to their offices with policies in place that make that status clear.
articles.abstract: Nearly 40 percent of Americans over the age of 18 remain unvaccinated, and could return to their offices with policies in place that make that status clear.
articles.lead_paragraph: Vincent Taranto has felt like less of a pariah at work in the last few days.
articles.byline: By Sydney Ember and Coral Murphy Marcos

articles.headline: The Kindergarten Exodus
articles.snippet: As the pandemic took hold, more than 1 million children did not enroll in local schools. Many of them were the most vulnerable: 5-year-olds in low-income neighborhoods.
articles.abstract: As the pandemic took hold, more than 1 million children did not enroll in local schools. Many of them were the most vulnerable: 5-year-olds in low-income neighborhoods.
articles.byline: By Dana Goldstein and Alicia Parlapiano

articles.headline: For G.O.P., Infrastructure Bill Is a Chance to Inch Away From Trump
articles.snippet: The former president’s efforts to bring down the bipartisan deal fell mostly on deaf ears among Republicans, signaling his waning influence on Capitol Hill. Can it last?
articles.abstract: The former president’s efforts to bring down the bipartisan deal fell mostly on deaf ears among Republicans, signaling his waning influence on Capitol Hill. Can it last?
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Donald J. Trump tried mightily to kill the $1 trillion infrastructure bill, hurling the kind of insult-laden statements and threats of primary challenges that for years sent a chill down Republican spines.
articles.byline: By Luke Broadwater and Emily Cochrane

articles.headline: After Trumka’s Death, A.F.L.-C.I.O. Faces a Crossroads
articles.snippet: For years, influencing political outcomes has been the priority. Some are calling for more emphasis on basic organizing.
articles.abstract: For years, influencing political outcomes has been the priority. Some are calling for more emphasis on basic organizing.
articles.lead_paragraph: Richard Trumka’s 12 years as A.F.L.-C.I.O. president coincided with the continued decline of organized labor but also moments of opportunity, like the election of a devoutly pro-labor U.S. president. With Mr. Trumka’s death last week, the federation faces a fundamental question: What is the A.F.L.-C.I.O.’s purpose?

articles.headline: As Afghan Cities Fall to Taliban, Brutal New Chapter Unfolds
articles.snippet: “This is now a different kind of war, reminiscent of Syria.” The seizure of five capitals has amplified fears about Afghanistan’s future after the U.S. withdrawal.
articles.abstract: “This is now a different kind of war, reminiscent of Syria.” The seizure of five capitals has amplified fears about Afghanistan’s future after the U.S. withdrawal.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban seized three Afghan cities on Sunday, including the commercial hub of Kunduz, officials said, escalating a sweeping offensive that has claimed five provincial capitals in three days and shown how little control the government has over the country without American military power to protect it.
articles.byline: By Christina Goldbaum, Najim Rahim, Sharif Hassan and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

articles.headline: As Taliban Capture Cities, U.S. Says Afghan Forces Must Fend for Themselves
articles.snippet: The muted American response to the Taliban siege shows in no uncertain terms that the U.S. war in Afghanistan is over.
articles.abstract: The muted American response to the Taliban siege shows in no uncertain terms that the U.S. war in Afghanistan is over.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If the Taliban had seized three provincial capitals in northern Afghanistan a year ago, like they did on Sunday, the American response would most likely have been ferocious. Fighter jets and helicopter gunships would have responded in force, beating back the Islamist group or, at the very least, stalling its advance.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper, Katie Rogers and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

articles.headline: Business Travel Resumes, Hesitantly
articles.snippet: Convention centers are reopening. Hotels and airlines report an uptick in bookings. But the rise in virus cases has tempered forecasts for a major recovery.
articles.abstract: Convention centers are reopening. Hotels and airlines report an uptick in bookings. But the rise in virus cases has tempered forecasts for a major recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: Business travel has started again, but in fits and starts.

articles.headline: Even Your Allergist Is Now Investing in Start-Ups
articles.snippet: The once-clubby world of start-up deal making known as “angel investing” has had an influx of new participants. It’s part of a wider boom in ever-riskier investments.
articles.abstract: The once-clubby world of start-up deal making known as “angel investing” has had an influx of new participants. It’s part of a wider boom in ever-riskier investments.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — On a recent Wednesday evening, 60 people gathered in a virtual conference room to discuss start-up investments. Among them were a professional poker player from Arizona, an allergist in California and a kombucha maker from Tennessee. All were members of Angel Squad, a six-month $2,500 program that aims to help people break into the clubby world of venture capital as individual investors, known as “angels.”

articles.headline: The Stigma of a Scarlet E
articles.snippet: Eviction cases — called Scarlet E’s — are a stubborn blot on a renter’s history. Piecemeal privacy legislation in some states may not be enough to protect millions of struggling tenants.
articles.abstract: Eviction cases — called Scarlet E’s — are a stubborn blot on a renter’s history. Piecemeal privacy legislation in some states may not be enough to protect millions of struggling tenants.
articles.lead_paragraph: The apartment was just what Chanque Jones needed: four bedrooms, and $500 cheaper than the run-down house she had been renting back in Chicago. It was a fresh start for her three sons, as well as for her mobile manicure business.

articles.headline: Text Memes Are Taking Over Instagram
articles.snippet: Fueled by Gen Z, text-heavy meme posts, often paired with nonsensically unrelated pictures, are turning the photo and video app into a destination for written expression.
articles.abstract: Fueled by Gen Z, text-heavy meme posts, often paired with nonsensically unrelated pictures, are turning the photo and video app into a destination for written expression.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Last month, the singer Courtney Love, who is a keen observer of social media trends, posted a cryptic message on Instagram.

articles.headline: On Afghanistan’s Front Line, There Are No Good Choices
articles.snippet: For the past month, Kandahar, Afghanistan’s second-largest city, has been under siege by Taliban fighters. Families stuck between them and government forces have almost nowhere to go.
articles.abstract: For the past month, Kandahar, Afghanistan’s second-largest city, has been under siege by Taliban fighters. Families stuck between them and government forces have almost nowhere to go.
articles.lead_paragraph: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan — As the first chatter of gunfire began, a police unit tested its heavy machine gun. The gunner pointed the barrel in the vicinity of the Taliban front line and fired in an ear-shattering clap clap clap. Where the bullets landed was anyone’s guess.
articles.byline: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Fahim Abed and Jim Huylebroek
